results.title: Propaganda: resource material from WW1 and WW2.
results.brief_description: This video presents black and white propaganda footage from WW1 and WW2. Part 1 presents excerpts from World War I propaganda in Germany and Australia. Shows early animation/political cartoons by Harry Julius and an excerpt from a Charlie Chaplin film “The Liberty Bond”. Part 2 presents excerpts from World War II propaganda in Australia, Germany and Britain. Includes excerpts by directors Leni Riefenstahl, Humphrey Jennings, Harry Watt and Karl Ritter. The success of cinema propaganda was well established by World War Two. In Germany, Goebbel’s Ministry for National Enlightenment and Propaganda, Britain had its Ministry of Information, in the USA film propaganda was only one part of the total propaganda picture and in Australia we had the Commonwealth Dept. of Information which was responsible for official propaganda and news items.

results.title: Prop shivs, cuffs and knuckle duster
results.material_description: Rubber, plastic, metal, paper, cotton, pencil, scissors, toothbrushes
results.brief_description: Wentworth’s impact on the local industry is just as important as its global popularity, providing countless opportunities for women on both sides of the camera. It also explores complex female-focused themes including institutionalised power, female transgression and violence, motherhood and LGBTQIA+ sexuality.
results.title_for_label: Props - [7 x shivs + fake knuckle duster and fake cuffs from the set of Wentworth]
results.description:
7 x varied shivs, fake knuckle duster and fake cuffs from the set of Wentworth the TV series.

Taken from medium/material desc during data ugrade: 001: maleable rubber cast to look like plastic bottles, and red paint splatters to give the impression of blood.

002: A prop crafted to look like a shiv for Wentworth. One half of a pair of scissors with a light brown cotton material bandaged around the handle to give more grip. The original handle is white plastic. The brand of scissor is engraved on the blade and says: Kokuyo P250

003: A prop crafted to look like a shiv for Wentworth. Handle created with wrapped blue material wrapped around and secured with white cotton thread. The blade is inserted at the end of the pencil on the side, and tied in and looped through the circular holes with a synthetic thin black rope.

004: A prop crafted to look like a shiv for Wentworth. Red and white coloured toothbrush which has had the bristles cut off. It has then been melted and had a burnished blade embedded at the top.

005: A prop crafted to look like a shiv for Wentworth. Orange and white coloured toothbrush which has had the bristles cut off. It has then been melted flat and a piece ofsilver rubber(part of it is hardened) has been attached to it to resemble a blade. Thin elastic bands have been wound around the top to keep the blade secure. There is also clear sticky tape at the top of the blade. There are a number of thin elastic bands bound around the toothbrush handle to give more grip.

006: A prop crafted to look like a shiv for Wentworth. Blue and white coloured toothbrush which has had the bristles cut off. It has then been melted and had a burnished blade embedded at the top.

007: 2B greylead pencil and a blade crafted to create a shiv as a Wentworth prop. The ‘copperplate’ branded pencil has been shaved away at the middle to create a point of grip. The razor blade has been slotted down the centre of the pencil and tied in with light grey cotton.

008: 2B greylead pencil and a blade crafted to create a shiv as a Wentworth prop. The ‘copperplate’ branded pencil has been shaved away at the middle to create a point of grip. The razor blade has been slotted down the centre of the pencil and tied in with light grey cotton.

009: Handcuff prop.
Cast from a pair of Smith and Wesson model 100 standard chain handcuffs and set in rubber. The detail on the cuffs says: TRADE 477870 M-100 Made in U.S.A. Marcas registradas Smith and Wesson Houlton M.

010: Clear ziplock bag with a handwritten label in black biro that says: Reject Shivs
The brand of the bag is Hercules. Used to store reject shivs.

results.title: Proofreading and editing skills [text]
results.creator_credit: Helen Sutton, Debra Smith and CareerTrack Publications
results.brief_description: This workbook accompanies the video set and looks at improving the important skills of proofreading and editing.

results.title: Proofreading & editing skills: spelling and usage. Vol.3
results.brief_description: This video seminar presentation led by Debra Smith and Helen Sutton looks at spelling and usage of words in the pursuit of achieving total accuracy in written communication. Areas covered include: a fun test to see how good your spelling is; how and when to use your computer’s spellchecker; capitalisation rules; when to use numbers and when to use words (50 or fifty); 200 frequently misspelled words; frequently misused words; the most commonly confused pairs of words and a proofreading post-test to see how much you’ve learnt.

results.title: Proofreading & editing skills: grammar and punctuation. Vol.2
results.brief_description: Led by Debra Smith and Helen Sutton, this seminar presentation video aims at teaching how to achieving total accuracy in written communication. This volume concentrates on: a basic review of sentence structure; how to fix run-on sentences; subject/verb agreement rules; noun/pronoun agreement rules; who vs. whom, me vs. myself; essential rules for using commas; use of semicolons; dashes and parentheses; and when to use quotations.

results.title: Proofreading & editing skills: grammar and punctuation. Vol.1
results.brief_description: This live video seminar presentation with Debra Smith and Helen Sutton begins with a one-page pre-test to determine your current proofreading accuracy. By the end of the program you’ll be able to see and measure your improvement! Some of the skills learned include: spotting common typographical errors; how to correct writing without changing the meaning; overcoming monotony and staying alert when proofreading; creating distance from your work so you can coorect your own errors; how to use proofreader’s marks for consistency and time saving and how to stay alert and accurate.

results.title: Proof of power
results.brief_description: Sponsored by the Ford Motor Company, this film deals with the scientific measurement of tractor power, and its application in primary production. The American sequence is included by courtesy of the University of Nebraska, USA.

results.title: Proof (Captioned)
results.creator_credit: Jocelyn Moorhouse, Lynda House and House and Moorhouse Films
results.brief_description: Winner of 7 Australian Film Institute awards, “Proof” is a provocative and engrossing film about a man’s obsessive search for truth. Martin (Hugo Weaving) has been blind from birth. He trusts no-one, except for the camera which has replaced his eyes. His photos are proof that the world he senses is the same as other people see. Then he meets a young kitchen hand, Andy, whose honesty and kindness allow Martin to trust for the first time - until Martin’s jealous housekeeper, Celia, sets out to destroy this relationship. Written and directed by Jocelyn Moorhouse who won a 1992 Victorian Premier’s Literary Award for her screenplay.
